The Washougal Community Education Preschool will be starting classes on Monday, September 21st instead of September 14th.

The Washougal School District is working to provide limited on-site preschool classes, but it has been determined that additional time is needed to ensure all required safety protocols are appropriately in place for students and staff.

This one-week delay will allow us to have the required safety measures, necessary curriculum changes, and classroom settings properly prepared to comprehensively support on-site learning in small cohorts.

We understand that students and families are excited to start preschool as planned, however, we appreciate your flexibility. Teachers will be providing Dojo videos by Friday, September 18th to familiarize you with your classroom and the steps in place for your preschool arrival and departure.

Please contact Lisa Young at 360-954-3895 or lisa.young@washougalsd.org.
if you have any questions about this change.

We are excited to see all of you the week of September 21st!

We are very excited to announce that Washougal has adopted a new communication tool to keep parents and guardians in the loop. ParentSquare is designed to keep students and families fully informed about school activities by integrating many of the systems we already use so that information is more easily accessible to everyone in the district. ParentSquare provides a safe, secure and streamlined way for our school principals, teachers, staff and parents to:

Send and receive school and class information; share images and files; and see detailed calendar items ... all in one centralized place!

Family members should receive an email this afternoon from ParentSquare with links to sign up, or can visit our website for information. http://www.washougal.k12.wa.us/parentsquare/

“Our students are sharing their eco-column pictures on a padlet as a way to compare progress and just have a little fun looking at the different growth,” said science teacher Patrick Rice. “We thought it would be a way to increase engagement and interaction between students in this time of distance education.”

Plant and student growth have been evident!

Washougal elementary students are receiving science kits delivered by school buses to design and perform experiments. In this activity, "Keep the Coffee Hot", Columbia River Gorge Elementary students Sophie & Ella used household materials like foil, socks, paper, and plastic wrap, along with cups filled with hot water, to study the insulating properties of different materials. Students filled the cups with hot water, sealed them with the materials, and then waited a set amount of time. They then measure the temperature of the water to see which insulator retained the most heat in the cup.

Younger students are working with a kit called "Sheltering our Furry Friends."

Science kits like these help students continue learning at home, ensuring they learn key concepts and science standards they will build upon in future grades.

Wendy Morrill will be the next principal to lead Hathaway Elementary School according to an announcement made Monday, May 4 by Dr. Mary Templeton, WSD superintendent.
“Wendy brings a wealth of experience, desire and passion to this work and we are very excited to officially welcome her to the Hathaway community,” she said in an email to staff.
Morrill is a veteran teacher with the Washougal School District for 19 years, and most recently served as Interim Principal, Dean of Students, as well as being District BEST Coordinator, New Teacher Mentor, and Title I and LAP Coordinator.
She was selected from a talented candidate pool in a competitive process that included input and participation from the Hathaway staff and parents. “Thank you to the many staff members who helped guide this process, as well as those who served on the interview panel,” said Templeton.

“We are confident that Wendy will continue to support the students and staff of Hathaway, as she has since joining the staff as the interim principal in February,” she said. “Please join us in congratulating Wendy!”

Every family is doing their best with figuring out distance learning. Here is a tip from ESD112. Follow the link for more helpful advice.
LET OFF SOME STEAM AND BE CREATIVE
If the kids are having a hard time focusing, getting frustrated easily, or acting out, it may be time for a short break. Spend 15 minutes playing a game, pulling a few weeds in the garden or taking a quick walk around the block. When it’s time for lunch, get the kids involved in making their own simple meals and participating in cleanup afterward. It’s a great way for them to learn basic cooking skills and will keep them busy for up to an hour.

ESD 112 Parent Tip:
“What’s working well for us is to be mindful that we all need to be flexible when it comes to our own expectations for learning. Our kids are beginning to understand that learning can look different from one day to the next and that’s okay.” —Jenna

Every family is doing their best with figuring out distance learning. Here is a tip from ESD112. Follow the link for more helpful advice.
SET A SCHEDULE FOR WORK AND PLAY
Don’t expect to be able to replicate a traditional school day at home. Take some pressure off of the situation by remembering that a typical school day is comprised of more than just learning periods; it also includes things like recess and lunch time. Aim for a more realistic schedule that includes one to three solid hours of learning per day, and structure in playtime, rest and meal breaks.
ESD 112 Parent Tip: “I wrote and posted a schedule for the kids to follow every day, and it really helped reduce frustrations by setting up expectations for them. My second grader needs routine to function, so this was critical for him. He was also reassured seeing the planned breaks for video games or outside time that broke up his day.” —Melissa

Thanks to community support, weekend food bags continue to be distributed to Washougal students who qualify for free or reduced lunches or who’s families have been hit hard financially due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

The food is available from 10am to noon each Friday at Hamllik Park - 4300 Addy Street or Hathaway Elementary - 630 24th Street. If you are a family in need, register by sending an email to nancy.nass.boon@washougalsd.org or come to a distribution site on Friday.

“The goal is to provide two breakfast items, two lunch/dinner items and two snacks,” said Nancy Boon, WSD Family Resource Coordinator. “A typical bag has individual oatmeal packets, mac and cheese, ramen noodles and a few snacks. All the food is non-perishable.”

Children's Home Society is taking donations to support this program. Monetary donations, as well as food, can be dropped off at 1702 C Street, Washougal on Tuesday or Thursday between noon and 3pm. There is a particular need for fruit - for example, individual fruit cups. Contact CHS for more information 835-7802.

Participation is vital for our region, it helps guide federal funding to areas experiencing growth, provide data for redistricting for local, state, and federal governments, and demographics about our changing population.

Jemtegaard Middle School
February 2 at 10:42 PM ·

The 8th grade students are in their final semester at Jemtegaard so now begins the transition to high school. One of the most important factors in determining graduation success is the strength and unity of the class.
On Thursday our work began with our Challenge Day. It was called 'I Am, We Are.' as we worked with students to learn more about each other. Students did a great job getting out of their comfort zone and meeting people outside of their regular friendship groups.

The day focused not only on team building but focusing on issues that impact teenagers. As we saw throughout the day our students share many of the same hopes, dreams and concerns. A great day for our future high school students. Thank you to James Layman from the Association of Washington Student Leaders for his work that day. A great day to be a Husky.

At the January 28, 2020 Washougal School District Board of Directors meeting, the school board heard from a committee formed to study school start times across the district. After a thorough process, involving collecting input, reviewing research and feedback, and weighing challenges associated with a change against possible benefits, the committee recommended that the superintendent keep start times as they are currently for the 2020-2021 school year.

The start time committee included parents, teachers, and other staff, and met in October 2019 and January 2020. The committee gathered feedback via a survey of students, families, staff and patrons, gathering more than 1,300 responses. The committee expressed appreciation for those who brought this idea forward for study, and are also appreciative of family members, students, and staff who participated in the survey, helping guide the recommendation.

January is School Board Recognition Month. Join other district families, staff, and students as we say “thank you” to each of our school board members. Board members are a crucial bridge between the community and schools, and their efforts are instrumental in helping all students rise!

DONNA SINCLAIR
District 3
Donna Sinclair was sworn into office on December 12, 2017.
An adjunct History professor at Washington State University Vancouver, she has worked as a public historian since the late 1990s, and has written about the Vancouver National Historic Reserve and Columbia River History, as well as the U.S. Forest Service. She is currently working with the National Park Service to write a history of Vancouver Barracks.
Donna Sinclair earned a bachelor’s degree from Washington State University Vancouver while raising three children as a single parent. She went on to obtain a Master’s in History and Ph.D. in Urban Studies from Portland State University.
Because of her passion for education, she is strongly committed to ensuring that all students have access to quality schools.

The 2020 Census happens this year! By April 1, 2020, every home in the US will receive an invitation to participate in the 2020 Census. Participation is vital for our region, it helps guide federal funding to areas experiencing growth, provide data for redistricting for local, state, and federal governments, and demographics about our changing population.

Households can complete the survey online, by mail, or over the phone. The data shared is kept confidential per federal law. Learn more about this important process, what to expect, and how to participate by visiting https://2020census.gov/
